citations.narrative:
APHIS Officials reviewed a social media photo that was posted on 07-November-2024 of a White-Throated Capuchin on
the shoulder of a patron during public exhibition. In the photo the primate is sitting on an adult patron’s shoulder, between
the two patrons, and in close proximity to the faces of the members of the public. The facility representative viewed the
photo and confirmed that is the method in which he routinely exhibits his animals and he is seen in the photo. Allowing
animals to climb on the heads, necks, and shoulders of the public is not a method of handling with minimal risk to the
public and to the animal. It can lead to zoonotic disease transmission, injury to animals and/or the public. The licensee
must ensure that during public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and
to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public to assure the
safety of animals and the public. Correct by, 11-June-2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Eric Irvin, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
